name: Supernatural Horror Theme
description: Ghosts, hauntings, curses, possession, the unseen world, ancient evils, the veil between worlds, things that shouldn't exist but do

writing_rules.message: WARNING: This theme deals with entities that defy natural law. Prolonged exposure may result in narrative contamination.

never_explain_the_supernatural: Never provide definitive explanations for supernatural events. Leave room for doubt.
Never confirm the nature of supernatural entities. Let them remain ambiguous.
Never resolve supernatural mysteries. Let them linger and fester.

greetings: The {boundary} between worlds is {state}. You might {cross_it}.
They're watching. They've always been watching.
farewells: They'll remember you. They always remember the curious.
The {veil} is thinning. Don't stay too long.
What you saw... was it {real} or {manifestation}?
The {ritual} isn't complete. It never will be.
You brought something back with you. It's in your {possession}.

templates: The {boundary} between {worlds} is thinning. {entity} is trying to {cross_over}. {player_role}.
A {subgenre} game where {occult_practice} awakens {ancient_evil}. {mechanic} determines the outcome.
supernatural_phenomena: apparitions that only appear in reflections
time loops that reset at death
entities: ghosts that remember futures that haven't happened yet
demons that wear the faces of the living
spirits that exist in the spaces between atoms
ancient gods that slumber in suburban basements
cursed objects that grant wishes at a terrible cost
haunted_locations: abandoned asylums where the walls whisper
old houses where the floor plan changes
hotels where guests check in but never check out
forests where the trees watch you
hospitals where the dead outnumber the living

reality_uncertainty: Describe {event} from multiple perspectives that contradict each other.
Show {evidence} that could be interpreted as {natural_explanation} or {supernatural_explanation}.
Have {character} experience {phenomenon} but find no physical proof.
Create {situation} where {natural_cause} and {supernatural_cause} are equally plausible.
temporal_disruption: Have {event} occur before its apparent cause.
Show {character} experiencing memories of events that haven't happened yet.
Create {situation} where time flows differently for different characters.
Have {object} show signs of both past and future states simultaneously.
supernatural_ambiguity: Describe {entity} in terms that could apply to {natural_phenomenon} or {supernatural_being}.
Show {evidence} that disappears when examined closely.

abandoned_asylum.central_paradox: The asylum was meant to heal, but the treatments created something worse. The patients never left - they transformed.
untrustworthy_elements: doors that lead to different rooms depending on who opens them
voices that repeat conversations from other timelines
medical equipment that operates on principles unknown to science
shadows that move independently of light sources

cursed_house.central_paradox: The house wasn't built on cursed land - the land became cursed because the house was built there. The architecture itself is the curse.
untrustworthy_elements: rooms that appear in different locations
windows that show different views depending on the time of day
stairs that lead to impossible spaces
reflections that don't match the room they're in
clocks that run backward when no one is watching

revelation_patterns: The {phenomenon} isn't {supernatural_explanation} - it's {alternative_explanation}. But that doesn't explain {unexplained_aspect}.
The {event} wasn't caused by {apparent_cause} - it was caused by {supernatural_cause}. But {contradictory_evidence} complicates this.
